revision.text:
{{Infobox musical artist | name = Georges Garvarentz
Ժորժ Տիրան Կառվարենց | image = Georges Garvarentz n Charles Aznavour.jpg | caption = Georges Garvarentz (with Charles Aznavour on the left) | image_size = | background = non_performing_personnel | birth_name = | alias = George Diran Wem | birth_date = 1 April 1932 |birth_place =[[Athens]], [[Greece]] | death_date = {{death date and age|df=yes|1993|3|19|1932|4|1}} |death_place =[[Paris]], [[France]] | origin = {{flagicon|France}} [[Paris]], [[France]] | instrument = | genre = [[Pop music|Pop]], [[chanson]], [[film score]] | occupation = [[Composer]] | years_active = 1950–1993 | label = [[EMI]] | associated_acts = | website = {{url|fan.aznavour.free.fr/hommageGG.htm}} | current_members = | past_members = }} '''Georges Diran Garvarentz''' ({{lang-hy|Ժորժ Տիրան Կառվարենց}}, 1 April 1932 - 19 March 1993) was an [[Armenia]]n-[[France|French]] [[composer]], noted for his music for films and [[Charles Aznavour]]'s songs. ==Biography== Georges Garvarentz was born in [[Athens]], [[Greece]], to a family of [[Armenians|Armenian]] immigrants. His father, literature professor and [[poet]] Kevork Garvarentz, was the author of the Armenian military anthem.[http://www.cilicia.com/armo_files_music_harach.html Harach Nahadag - March of Armenina volunteers] In 1942 Garvarentz's family moved to [[Paris]], [[France]], where Georges attended [[Conservatoire de Paris]]. ==Career== In 1956 Georges met Charles Aznavour and started writing music for his songs. Together they wrote over 100 songs, including "Prends garde à toi" (1956), "Et pourtant" (1962), "Il faut saisir sa chance" (1962), "[[Retiens la nuit]]" (1962), "[[La plus belle pour aller danser]]" (1964), "[[Hier encore]]" (1964), "Paris au mois d'août" ("Paris in August", 1966), "[[Une Vie D'amour (song)|Une vie d'amour]]" (1980). In 1965 Georges married Charles Aznavour's sister, Aida Aznavourian. Georges Garvarentz also composed over 150 [[film score]]s, including scores for ''[[Un taxi pour Tobrouk]]'' (1960), ''[[Tales of Paris|Les Parisiennes]]'' (1962), ''[[The Devil and the Ten Commandments]]'' (1962), ''[[Rat Trap (film)|Le Rat d'Amérique]]'' (1963), ''[[That Man in Istanbul]]'' (1965), ''[[The Sultans (film)|The Sultans]]'' (1966), ''[[The Sea Pirate|Surcouf, le tigre des sept mers]]'' (1966), ''[[Triple Cross (1966 film)|Triple Cross]]'' (1966), ''[[The Peking Medallion]]'' (1967), ''Caroline chérie'' (1968), ''[[They Came to Rob Las Vegas]]'' (1968), ''[[The Southern Star (film)|The Southern Star]]'' (1969), ''[[The Heist (1970 film)|The Heist]]'' (1970), ''[[Love Me Strangely]]'' (1971), ''[[Someone Behind the Door]]'' (1971), ''[[The Pebbles of Etratat]]'' (1972), ''[[Murder in a Blue World]]'' (1973), ''[[Killer Force]]'' (1976), ''[[Teheran 43]]'' (1981), ''[[Hambone and Hillie]]'' (1983), ''[[The Triumphs of a Man Called Horse]]'' (1983), ''[[Too Scared to Scream]]'' (1985), ''Yiddish Connection'' (1986), ''[[A Star for Two]]'' (1991), and ''Catorce estaciones'' (1991) In 1979 he wrote the score to ''[[The Golden Lady]]'', and co-wrote the title song for [[The Three Degrees]], together with lead singer [[Sheila Ferguson]]. Garvarentz is the author of a musical comedy ''Deux anges sont venus'' and an [[operetta]] ''Douchka''.[http://perso.orange.fr/anao/oeuvre/douchka.html Douchka] {{in lang|fr}} == Awards and recognition == * In 1964 Garvarentz was awarded a special prize by the Chansonnier society * In 1989 Garvarentz has received a [[Gemini award]] for the Best Original Music Score - Program or Miniseries [http://theenvelope.latimes.com/extras/lostmind/year/1989/1989gemini.htm 1989 4th Gemini Awards] ==References== {{reflist|1}} == External links == *[https://web.archive.org/web/20130213112714/http://www.armenews.com/article.php3?id_article=74992 "Pour toi Arménie"] {{in lang|fr}} *(fr) Georges Garvarentz et la musique de film, Daniel Bastié,Ed.Ménadès (2019) (IBNS : 978-2960226232) *{{IMDb name|id=0006095|name=Georges Garvarentz}} *[http://www.encyclopedisque.fr/artiste/6777.html Georges Garvarentz at Encyclopédisque] {{in lang|fr}} {{Aznavour}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Garvarentz, Georges}} [[Category:French songwriters]] [[Category:French Armenians]] [[Category:Greek Armenians]] [[Category:Greek emigrants to France]] [[Category:People from Athens]] [[Category:1932 births]] [[Category:1993 deaths]] [[Category:20th-century French musicians]] [[Category:French operetta composers]] [[Category:French film score composers]] [[Category:Male film score composers]] [[Category:20th-century French male musicians]]
